{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3171680,"name":"","username":"sgtrupia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-23T19:09:34.896Z","cooked":"

@Peter_Johnson Just wondering if this camera is supported in the latest image:

Raspberry Pi

Buy a Raspberry Pi Global Shutter Camera – Raspberry Pi

A specialised camera for fast motion photography and machine vision applications

It uses a Sony IMX296 sensor

Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-23T19:09:34.896Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":242,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":1235.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.raspberrypi.com/products/raspberry-pi-global-shutter-camera/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Buy a Raspberry Pi Global Shutter Camera – Raspberry Pi","clicks":9},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/reading-rpi-camera-with-rpi-4-and-python/451900/5","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Reading rpi camera with rpi 4 and python","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58236,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3171684,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-23T19:15:25.258Z","cooked":"

Yes, it should, although you need to edit /boot/config.txt to load the appropriate imx296 driver overlay, as auto-detect doesn’t seem to work for V4L2. We need to add info on how to do this to the docs.

Pi Camera Configuration - PhotonVision Docs

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-23T19:29:25.080Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":111,"readers_count":110,"score":42.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.photonvision.org/en/latest/docs/hardware/picamconfig.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pi Camera Configuration - PhotonVision Docs","clicks":31}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":34970,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172014,"name":"","username":"sgtrupia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T04:23:31.249Z","cooked":"

Thanks for the input.

We updated the config.txt file to include the imx296.

SSH’ed into the Pi and ran “libcamera-hello --list-cameras” :

0 : imx296 [1456x1088] (/base/soc/i2c0mux/i2c@1/imx296@1a)
Modes: ‘SRGGB10_CSI2P’ : 1456x1088 [60.38 fps - (0, 0)/1456x1088 crop]

Ran libcamera-still : captured a jpg, looked good

Ran libcamera-vid : captured an h264 encoded video, transferred the file to Windows, looked good

But when running the multi-camera streaming application, or our vision application (via uploaded Python file), we get tons of:

CS: ERROR: ioctl VIDIOC_QBUF failed at UsbCameraImpl.cpp:719: Invalid argument (UsbUtil.cpp:156)
CS: WARNING: rPi Camera 0: could not queue buffer 0 (UsbCameraImpl.cpp:720)

Vision Settings says that the camera is connected, but when clicking on “Open Stream” we get:

USB device path: /dev/video0

Alternate device path: /dev/v4l/by-path/platform-fe801000.csi-video-index0

Supported Video Modes: (no modes show and no image is displayed)

We tried several camera settings (w, h, fps).

We are running the 64-bit version of the WPILibPi image, rev 2023.2.1.

What do you recommend as a next step? Are there any other utilities or tools that might help to determine what is happening here?

Thanks again for all your help!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T04:23:31.249Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":29.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58236,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172022,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T05:05:33.015Z","cooked":"

You have to set the resolution in the camera settings (in the web interface) to exactly the supported mode as reported by libcamera. The V4L2 compatibility layer is really terrible for MIPI cameras now and we don’t have libcamera support implemented.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T05:06:55.092Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":84,"readers_count":83,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58236,"username":"sgtrupia","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/5","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172317,"name":"","username":"sgtrupia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T19:40:18.362Z","cooked":"

@Peter_Johnson We set the w, h and fps exactly as reported by libcamera-hello --list-cameras and still saw the same errors with Pi GS camera.

Here is our config.txt:

For more options and information see

Raspberry Pi Documentation - Configuration

Some settings may impact device functionality. See link above for details

uncomment if you get no picture on HDMI for a default “safe” mode

#hdmi_safe=1

uncomment the following to adjust overscan. Use positive numbers if console

goes off screen, and negative if there is too much border

#overscan_left=16
#overscan_right=16
#overscan_top=16
#overscan_bottom=16

uncomment to force a console size. By default it will be display’s size minus

overscan.

#framebuffer_width=1280
#framebuffer_height=720

uncomment if hdmi display is not detected and composite is being output

#hdmi_force_hotplug=1

uncomment to force a specific HDMI mode (this will force VGA)

#hdmi_group=1
#hdmi_mode=1

uncomment to force a HDMI mode rather than DVI. This can make audio work in

DMT (computer monitor) modes

#hdmi_drive=2

uncomment to increase signal to HDMI, if you have interference, blanking, or

no display

#config_hdmi_boost=4

uncomment for composite PAL

#sdtv_mode=2

#uncomment to overclock the arm. 700 MHz is the default.
#arm_freq=800

Uncomment some or all of these to enable the optional hardware interfaces

#dtparam=i2c_arm=on
#dtparam=i2s=on
#dtparam=spi=on

Uncomment this to enable infrared communication.

#dtoverlay=gpio-ir,gpio_pin=17
#dtoverlay=gpio-ir-tx,gpio_pin=18

Additional overlays and parameters are documented /boot/overlays/README

Enable audio (loads snd_bcm2835)

dtparam=audio=on

Enable camera

#camera_auto_detect=1
gpu_mem=128
disable_camera_led=1

Automatically load overlays for detected cameras

This generally doesn’t seem to work for V4L2 (what cscore uses);

Instead change this to 0 and uncomment the line for the sensor you want

to use.

Pi Camera Board v1.3: ov5647

Pi Camera Board v2: imx219

#camera_auto_detect=1

camera_auto_detect=0
#dtoverlay=imx219,media-controller=0
#dtoverlay=imx290,clock-frequency=74250000,media-controller=0
#dtoverlay=imx290,clock-frequency=37125000,media-controller=0
#dtoverlay=imx378,media-controller=0
#dtoverlay=ov5647,media-controller=0
#dtoverlay=ov9281,media-controller=0
dtoverlay=imx296

Automatically load overlays for detected DSI displays

display_auto_detect=1

Enable DRM VC4 V3D driver

dtoverlay=vc4-kms-v3d
max_framebuffers=2

Run in 64-bit mode

arm_64bit=1

Disable compensation for displays with overscan

disable_overscan=1

[cm4]

Enable host mode on the 2711 built-in XHCI USB controller.

This line should be removed if the legacy DWC2 controller is required

(e.g. for USB device mode) or if USB support is not required.

otg_mode=1

[all]

[pi4]

Run as fast as firmware / board allows

arm_boost=1

[all]

We have a Pi Camera 2, Pi HQ Camera and the Pi GS camera. So GS doesn’t seem to work, will Pi Camera or Pi HQ Camera work? Which of those require changes to config.txt? I think Pi Camera 2? Can you share the config for any of those that are known to work? I think you replied to another message about Pi Camera 2 to add the config, I will check that as well.

Thanks!

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T19:40:18.362Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":75,"readers_count":74,"score":95.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://urldefense.com/v3/__http://rpf.io/configtxt__;!!JoeW-IhCUkS0Jg!aJB4F2RYxTOFzTy6jjj8b27KhEP2lwL6FBHfkJ-Mhl5H-dUrxKodH2i1f3N2poxigO5j5hl0gg6T3vFG4gQwPFUOtQ%24","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Raspberry Pi Documentation - Configuration","clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58236,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172324,"name":"Matt","username":"thatmattguy","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatmattguy/{size}/222358_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T19:53:42.117Z","cooked":"

Are you sure you’re on the latest kernel? Absent that, you could try replacing cscore with photon-libcamera-gl-driver, though you would need to recompile that against the latest libcamera with the new stuff for the global shutter camera.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T19:53:42.117Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":51,"readers_count":50,"score":15.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"Matt","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37738,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172330,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:05:55.458Z","cooked":"

Any MIPI camera requires changes to config.txt. In addition to setting the resolution, you may need to change the pixel mode as well to something other than JPEG. It’s also worth looking at the output from dmesg to see if it’s reporting any errors regarding what’s being requested.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:05:55.458Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":20.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58236,"username":"sgtrupia","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/8","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3172798,"name":"","username":"sgtrupia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-25T16:55:27.249Z","cooked":"

Thanks to the suggestion from @Peter_Johnson, we replaced cscore for camera image capture in our vision processing code with the new version of PiCamera that is based on libcamera, and that worked! Thanks to all for your input!

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-25T16:55:27.249Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":46,"readers_count":45,"score":54.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58236,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3193793,"name":"BillDunlap","username":"BillDunlap","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/7ea924/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-19T20:41:17.280Z","cooked":"

Can you share the details (e.g., a github link) on how you changed the cscore-based code to use PiCamera?

-Bill

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-04-19T20:41:17.280Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":37,"readers_count":36,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431494,"topic_slug":"does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera","display_username":"BillDunlap","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":58236,"username":"sgtrupia","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16385,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/does-the-wpilibpi-image-support-the-pi-global-shutter-camera/431494/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3193810,"name":"","username":"sgtrupia","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/4bbf92/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-04-19T21:24:21.457Z","cooked":"

We have been running this code, that calls into Picamera2, on the WPILibPi image

from picamera2 import Picamera2
from libcamera import controls
from cscore import CameraServer

init

picam2 = Picamera2()

see page 19 of

https://datasheets.raspberrypi.com/camera/picamera2-manual.pdf

for detailed info about ‘size’ and ‘format’ that go into create_still_configuration()

assumes w and h have been set according to image dimension you want to capture

picam2_config = picam2.create_still_configuration( {‘size’: (w, h), ‘format’ : ‘RGB888’} )
picam2.configure(picam2_config)
picam2.start()

not sure this delay is required, but it what we used to do after init when using Picamera (1) before

no harm keeping it, since this is at init time

time.sleep(3)

printing the configuration is optional, but has been useful for debugging

print(picam2_config[“main”])

while True:

img = picam2.capture_array()
# do something useful with image here

You can still use cscore to output image to set it on SmartDashboard / Shuffleboard.
Picamera2 doesn’t change that.
So you would add to init:
outputStream = CameraServer.putVideo(“image”, w, h)

and in your image processing loop, you would just do:
outputStream.putFrame(img) # send to dashboard
